Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Rapid and Accurate Multi-Variable Optimization Software for Arrays of Heat Sinks
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to reduce the power required to cool the data and telecommunications centers that drive the internet age. Currently nearly 2.0% of the energy consumed in the United States is used to run such data centers and, often, half of this is used for cooling. The corresponding greenhouse gas emissions will also be reduced. Longer term this technology can be adapted to increasing the efficiency of air-conditioning/refrigeration and power generation. Commercially, the computational fluid dynamics software market the product will compete in is projected to grow from $1.3 billion at present to over $2 billion by 2022. It will also stimulate the growth of the manufacture of specialty heat sinks with optimal geometries for efficient thermal management.

This intellectual merit of this SBIR Phase I project is based on proposing to hybridize three common numerical methods, i.e., computational fluid dynamics (CFD), flow network modeling (FNM) and multi-variable optimization (MVO), a non-trivial objective. The result will be a software platform that can accurately and simultaneously optimize the geometry of an array of heat sinks found in various types of circuit packs, e.g., blade servers in data centers. This is not possible with CFD alone as it is too slow and it is not possible with FNM alone as it is not sufficiently accurate. The method of the hybrid approach to preserve the accuracy of CFD is to embed pre-computed, non-dimensional look-up tables of flow and thermal resistances from CFD simulations in an FNM. The software will accommodate both single-phase flows of air and water and evaporating/boiling flows of water and refrigerant, which requires modeling complex heat, mass and momentum transport phenomena. Experiments will validate its accuracy on thermal mock-ups of circuit packs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the major challenges associated with the continued evolution of telecommunications and computing hardware is heat removal. Next-generation wireless networks relying on 5-th generation (5G) technology and tapping into the full potential of machine learning and artificial intelligence, for example, demand that we accommodate larger heat loads, even as the size of the hardware shrinks. The result of this Phase I SBIR award has been to advance the development of two novel and enabling heat-removal technologies. The first technology is a compliant vapor chamber or CVC. It enables more efficient heat transfer from heat-generating integrated circuits to a heat sink. It relies on the same technology used in heat pipes, found in virtually every computer today. However, it provides them in a form factor suited to coupling heat-generating ICs to heat sinks and possesses the requisite compliance to accommodate variations in geometric tolerances that result in variable-geometry gaps between them. The second technology is a novel platform to optimize the geometry of heat sinks found telecommunications and computing hardware. By doing so the temperature difference between such heat sinks and the air or water coolant provided to them is minimized. The platform is enabled by a novel hybridization of three software technologies used by engineers designing heat-removal systems. These are flow network modeling (FNM), computational fluid dynamics (CFD) and multi-variable optimization (MVO). Overall, this technology, which is being developed as a software product, provides a means to rapidly, but accurately optimize the geometry of an array of heat sinks found in, for example, a blade sever.

   Combined the two aforementioned technologies will reduce the thermal resistance to heat transfer between where heat is generated in electronics and where it is absorbed by air or water coolant. This enables next-generation hardware in the telecommunications and computing industries. We also note that telecommunications and data centers consume about 200 TWhr/year of energy and produce about 30 million tons of CO2, with nearly half these numbers attributable to heat-removal hardware. This translates to 1% of global consumption and 0.3% of carbon emissions. They’re projected to consume 3000 TWh/yr of electricity by 2030. Our goal is to reduce global electricity consumption by 0.1-0.2% and CO2 emissions by more than 100 million metric tons as enhanced heat removal leads to less electricity usage by enabling the use of higher temperature coolants. Relatedly, oft-used cooling towers in refrigeration systems in telecommunications and data centers use 100 billion liters of water/yr in the US and we can vastly reduce this consumption via further penetration of free cooling, whereby ambient temperature air rather than refrigerated air is the coolant.
